unnormalised: Mumbai, Maharashtra – Inventory forecasting is becoming increasingly crucial for Indian manufacturers navigating volatile market conditions, particularly with the festive season approaching. A recent report by the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) highlights that inaccurate forecasting leads to significant losses, averaging around 7% of annual revenue for SMEs.

A recent report by the Confederation of Indian Industry (C I I) highlights that inaccurate forecasting leads to significant losses, averaging around seven percent of annual revenue for S M Es.

unnormalised: Leading institutions like IIM Ahmedabad are now offering specialized courses on leveraging AI and machine learning for predictive analytics in inventory management. This helps anticipate demand fluctuations, especially in sectors like textiles and FMCG, where trends can shift rapidly.

unnormalised: "Improved forecasting accuracy minimizes stockouts and reduces holding costs, directly impacting profitability," stated Mr. Sharma, a supply chain expert at Tata Steel, during a webinar on 20/07/2024. Many manufacturers are implementing advanced software solutions to gain better visibility into their supply chains and optimize inventory levels. The goal is to achieve a 'just-in-time' approach, reducing reliance on large warehouses and minimizing waste. A case study presented on 10/08/2024, at 14:30 hrs, showed how ABC Textiles in Tiruppur reduced inventory costs by 15% after implementing a new forecasting model. The Diwali season demand is expected to be accurately predicted by 15/10/2024.
